caption: Rivera del Bravo is a neighborhood in eastern Ciudad Juárez, Chihuahua, Mexico.
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: One of the newer neighborhoods in the city, Riviera del Bravo had many schools and strip malls.
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: A former state governor once described Riviera del Bravo as a model for future neighborhoods.
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: In an article in 2010, Alfredo Corchado of The Dallas Morning News wrote of Riviera del Bravo — "stories abound of gunfights, headless corpses and men in SUVs peering through dark tinted windows."
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: “We lived through the massacre of a lot of people. … We kept just going from work to home and didn’t go outside. … We thank God we are happy and healthy," says mother Isabel Moreno, 32.
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: Many families fled to El Paso, Texas, just north of Juarez.
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: Together El Pas and Juarez form the one of the largest international border communities on earth.
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: Sixty percent of Juarez's population was born elsewhere (mostly from southern Chihuahua and other parts of Mexico).
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: Over 60,000 people cross the border between Juarez and El Paso every day.
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: The town is named after Benito Juarez who made it his capital when exiled from central Mexico.
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: The gap between the rich and the poor in Juarez in only increasing. In the past decade in Mexico, the number of billionaires has multiplied, and the incomes of working people have fallen.
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: In 2008, Ciudad Juárez was designated as “The City of the Future” by the prestigious magazine “Foreign Direct Investment."
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: In 2010, Mexico's death toll in two years of cartel violence was estimated at 18,000. About 98% of crimes were never solved.
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: Since 2010, over than 10,000 businesses have closed, leaving tens of thousands unemployed.
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: Media reports, citing the Mexican census bureau, said that more than 500,000 people have abandoned Juárez because of fear of violence or endemic unemployment.
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: During the violence, many who lived in Rivera del Bravo fled to their native towns in southern Mexico.
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: "From one day to another, people just pick up and go, some never paying their debts to me, just disappear like the wind," said store clerk, Francisca Kika Lucas, 38, in 2010.
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: At the height of violence, some families stayed in Juarez — barely going outside except to work.
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: Once night fell, they said they'd locked their doors and watch T.V. to try to drown out the gunfire outside.
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: Toys for sale in a market stall.
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: There are no streetlights, no running water, no schools in the blue-collar neighborhoods of Juarez.
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: While some say the city is on the mend, in many ways the wounds of violence are still raw.
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: Used cowboy boots on sale on a curb.
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: "Unbelievable," said businessman Jorge Contreras Fornelli, in 2010, teary-eyed and shaking his head as he walked the block, pointing to the homes of former neighbors now living across the border. "The human cost is beyond belief."
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: Many wrestled with guilt for wanting to leave and fear that staying behind may cost them their lives.
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: Juarez's determination, some say, is a reflection of their city's storied past. In the 1980s, the city woke a country, leading a nationwide movement for democracy that finally reached Mexico City on a rainy night in July 2000.
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR

caption: That's when the National Action Party, or PAN, led by Vicente Fox, booted the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party out of office after 71 years in power. If there's hope for Juárez, it can only be found in it's residents.
creator: Kainaz Amaria/NPR
